9. He sought in many ways to escape this foolish lust,
desperate to be able to derive
some joy from comforting fruits,
And finally, with much sorrowing and sighing
he lay sick in bed refusing
nourishing food, and wished to be allowed to die;
but the Doctor Erasistratus understood
quickly that it was the suffering of Love.

10. But with whom could not be detected;
he diligently studied the youth,
too see, whenever anyone passed through the door,
if his Face did not flush red
or reveal by other signs what thoughts,
emotions or the inner forces
of a Person, stirring awake,
reveals through outward signs.

11. Yet nothing happened at all.
Then each time Stratonice came
into the room, alone or with her father Seleucus,
his pulse beat in his affected vein,
his voice broke into a stammer,
his Face was fiery red, he sweated freely:
in sum, all the signs which Sappho
described in her writing were there in him.

12. Although the Medical man now knew
from many signs on which Woman his senses fell,
he did not know how to help him;
nevertheless, seeing him daily appearing
in severe longing, with an oppressed soul
and his sickly flesh more and more destroyed,
he thought, “What counsel shall benefit here
so that King’s Son will not be lost?”

13. Had it not been his own Stepmother,
so terrible and rare a thing,
[the Doctor] would have informed the King earlier:
but at last, fortified by the kindness and great love
that he knew Seleucus bore his Son,
he was emboldened to speak or write to him
that the cause of his Son’s sickness was Love.

14. “But,” (he said) “it is a Love not to be cured,
since the beloved Woman
can never be obtained for him.”
The King, much affected by this, asked who it was.
